Local firewall rules
Device group post-rules
Shared post-rules
Intrazone-default
Interzone-default

A. Shared post-rulebase

The shared post-rulebase is evaluated after the pre-rulebase and before the default security rule

discussion.content:
Answer C
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/app-id/use-application-objects-in-policy/create-an-application-group
An application group is an object that contains applications that you want to treat similarly in policy. Application groups are useful for enabling access to applications that you explicitly sanction for use within your organization. Grouping sanctioned applications simplifies administration of your rulebases. Instead of having to update individual policy rules when there is a change in the applications you support, you can update only the affected application groups

C. Create an application group and add the email applications to it.

This approach allows the administrator to group specific email applications together and apply the same firewall rules to them. This can be more efficient and manageable than creating individual rules for each application.

Selected Answer: C
keyword, specific application 
so must be application group than application filter which is for dynamic app

Selected Answer: C
Answer C

Selected Answer: C
Answer C-- Asking for Specific applications

questions.question_text:
Which rule type is appropriate for matching traffic occurring within a specified zone?

How should the administrator configure the firewall to restrict users to specific email applications?

choices.C: Create an application group and add the email applications to it.
choices.B: Create an application filter and filter it on the collaboration category, email subcategory.
choices.A: Create an application filter and filter it on the collaboration category.
choices.D: Create an application group and add the email category to it.

discussion.content:
Answer B. 
HTTP/2 has allow which does not create a log-entry

Selected Answer: D
I think D

The question asks which protocol permits the traffic after detecting a machine-learning match.
Looking at the WildFire Inline ML Action column, only http2 has the action allow.
Other protocols (e.g., ftp, smb, imap) have either reset-both or alert, which would either block or just log the traffic.

Selected Answer: B
B:

IMAP is the only app in the profile that covers all the requirements to the question.

Why not HTTP? Not too sure how IMAP can be used for machine learning.
Action Alert: generates an alert for each application traffic flow. The alert is saved in the threat log.

Selected Answer: B
Is the correct answer

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer.
According to the screenshot, only imap, pop3 and smtp have a default (alert) action, which generates an alert for each application traffic flow. The alert is saved in the threat log.
